2416.00.text: Recall back to the global variable dictionary,

2418.94.text: which is a struct that we've made that basically has an int called size

2424.16.text: associated with it as well as an array of words,

2427.29.text: where word is a new data type.

2432.03.text: So to access, for instance, the size of the dictionary or the words array,

2436.91.text: then what you can do is just write 'dictionary.size,'

2439.84.text: similar to the way that you would just use any other variable.

2442.58.text: So if dictionary.size represents the size of the dictionary,

2459.02.text: because you would have to say 'dictionary.words at index i'

2463.13.text: and then do something based on that.

2466.05.text: So knowing that the dictionary has a certain size associated with it,

2469.95.text: as well as an array of words, to check if something's in the dictionary,

2473.72.text: then you would have to interate over the dictionary

2476.87.text: to check whether that word is found.

2480.61.text: Now, if you think back to lecture, when we talked about different ways to search for things,

2485.72.text: then remember that linear search probably isn't always the best way to go.

2490.69.text: But it definitely is one way to search for something.

2496.60.text: Sometimes you might find that you implement your find function with

2499.54.text: linear search at first and then get the rest of your program going.

2532.67.text: It shows su, but what is a word?

2538.31.text: This isn't a philosophical question but, rather, look at the type definitions.

2542.33.text: We have a boolean called 'found' as well as the array of characters

2549.57.text: So when you return lookup, you will want to check whether that word has been found or not.

2555.94.text: Now, knowing that the boolean found--found is the name of the boolean

2563.04.text: that's associated with every word--then how might you access that variable,

2569.66.text: thinking back to how we accessed the variables within dictionary?

2585.12.text: Similarly, when we have a word and, in this case, be careful because

2588.17.text: word is just any other data type, just like an int or a string.

2593.34.text: So you can't just say 'word' unless that's the name of it.

2599.64.text: You're going to have to have a variable with a name, and then once you have that,

2604.54.text: say that's called foo, for instance, then you can say 'foo.found,'

2609.98.text: and that will return you the boolean value of whether that word has been found or not.

2619.56.text: So then the next part of the pset is to implement scramble,

2626.96.text: whereby whenever the user inputs scramble--and that's already been dealt with

2631.63.text: here in the distribution code--you just need to implement

2634.28.text: the function scramble that has already instructed you to rotate the board 90° clockwise.

2643.17.text: As per the spec, the instructions say that the board rotates 90° clockwise

2647.38.text: such that the value at grid [0] [0] then moves to grid [0] [dimension -1.]

2656.18.text: In this case, for scramble, our dimension is 4, so 0-0 would then map to 0-3.

2678.24.text: Let's draw this out to see what it might look like.

2681.21.text: I'm not going to do a 4 x 4 grid but rather a 3 x 3 one.

2689.62.text: Let's say this is an inch 2D array.

2692.47.text: I'm just going to just have--all right.

2702.04.text: So say we want to scramble this; we want to rotate it 90° clockwise.

2712.11.text: We know that, as a starting point, the value at 0-0, which in this case is the number 0,

2722.32.text: is going to map to row 0, then column dimension -1.

2728.95.text: And so that, in this case, the dimension is 3.

2731.57.text: So then 0 would move to row 0, column 2.

2737.40.text: So we have the number 0 there.

2741.91.text: Essentially what we're doing is we're taking this,

2745.97.text: physically rotating it so then the 2 would go to this corner,

2752.84.text: the 8 would then go to this corner, the 6 to this one.

2757.62.text: And then the rest of it would look like--

2767.84.text: So that's what a grid looks like when you have successfully scrambled it.

2775.18.text: When you're implementing the scramble function, what you'll want to do

2777.41.text: is see, well, how can I replace these values?

2782.52.text: Is there some kind of pattern or some kind of formula to determine

2789.90.text: For instance, I might look to see that 3-4-5 here is a row.

2809.41.text: Similarly, I see 6-7-8 as a row, but then it's actually a column here.

2822.36.text: That's the pattern that I see right now, but there are probably a few other ones.

2827.83.text: Based on that, think of some kind of pattern, some kind of way.

2831.98.text: Once you've identified one, then you're going to want to reset the values in the grid.

2840.29.text: So grid 0-0 will become 6, grid 0-1 will become 3.

2845.48.text: But remember that you'll--for instance, if you reset this right away,

2852.99.text: say that grid 0-2 becomes 0 now, then you lose what 2 was there.

2869.17.text: So thinking back, it's not enough to just reassign right away.

2872.38.text: You'll probably want to make a temporary copy of something

2876.42.text: before you actually put it in at the right place.

2888.38.text: The last thing is to implement case insensitivity.

2891.86.text: If you look back, search to the spot in the spec where the user inputs a string.

2899.31.text: If you recall back, thinking back to--oh, I erased the map.

2902.70.text: If you think back to the map of your program, it's within the main function,

2910.30.text: so look to where you're dealing with the user-inputted string,

2913.85.text: and then within there, think of the tools that you learned from your

2918.26.text: crypto pset, pset 2, and then think of ways that you might be able to

2923.69.text: allow for user input as mixed case.

2928.64.text: So they could have a mix of uppercases and lowercases, but that should still be valid.

2933.98.text: In the dictionary, recall when we opened up that file, every word was stored as all uppercase.

2939.77.text: But we don't want the user to have to input uppercase all the time.

2945.88.text: Can anyone think of a way that we might be able to allow the user,

2952.15.text: even though they inputted all lowercase, for instance? Yeah?

2958.32.text: [Student] You could make it to upper?

2960.54.text: Yeah, exactly. You could make it to upper.

2963.47.text: So you could convert all of the letters to uppercase, and then

2967.67.text: that way you ensure that that is going to be an exact copy

2970.95.text: of whatever's found in the dictionary, if it's in the dictionary.

2975.41.text: Great. We have a little bit of time left.

2980.91.text: So some things that you might encounter in this pset is a need to know

2987.53.text: what your variables are at a certain point in time.

2992.40.text: Because in the spec we have the clear function that basically

2997.00.text: clears whatever you've drawn on the board, erases it all and then rewrites on top of that,

3005.50.text: you might, while you're writing your pset, not really want that to happen.

3010.63.text: Because you'll want to see, okay, once I enter in this scramble, for instance,

3013.81.text: once I enter in scramble, what does it do and what was it before, just for reference.

3019.72.text: So then what you might want to do is go back to your main function

3024.68.text: and comment out clear, for instance.

3031.53.text: So then when you run your program the next time,

3034.06.text: your program won't clear it instead and will just keep on printing on top of that.

3045.21.text: There are some other ways to debug as well.

3047.21.text: What you could do is you can include print f statements, I think.

3051.50.text: One thing that I saw in psets that I graded was that people included print f statements

3057.46.text: to print out variables at a certain point in time to keep track.

3062.71.text: But just make sure that at the end, once you've finished writing all your print f statements

3066.82.text: for you to keep track of things, that you comment them out afterwards,

3071.61.text: or delete them once you've finished.

3075.53.text: That's another way that you could do something; you could just write in a print f statement

3081.89.text: somewhere that's relevant and see, based on what the terminal prints out,

3088.95.text: Another way to do that, that we'll go into more detail during lecture,

3093.32.text: is GDB, which is a debugging tool.

3096.71.text: Essentially, when you run it, it'll go into your program and you can have it advance

3107.27.text: a single step at a time instead of evaluating everything.

3111.50.text: So then you can break it up into little steps, and then based on the way--

3114.77.text: and then along the way print things and see what the values are.

3120.23.text: And that helps you figure out where a bug in your code might be.

3127.83.text: What we could do right now is write a quick function and then

3132.97.text: see how we might be able to use GDB to see what's going on.

3139.78.text: So let's have an int main, and then what do we have as parameters to main?

3143.41.text: We have int arg c, and string arg v.

3152.69.text: I'm going to save this in walkthrough as GDB.z. All right.

3168.30.text: So how about let's just have a simple for loop; let's have 12.

3179.39.text: Let's also have an int named counter, and

3186.75.text: we can start that at 0. Okay.

3191.91.text: So at every point in the for loop, let's say that we want to increase counter

3197.76.text: or multiply it by whatever i is.

3206.98.text: This is a pretty short function.

3219.65.text: Let's make GDB. Oh! And then--Clang is smart.

3226.29.text: Tells me that I didn't include cs50.h.

3243.78.text: All right. So now we want to--

3256.16.text: Actually, sorry guys. I'm going to rename the file just because it's a bit confusing.

3272.74.text: All right. So now what we want to do is, we want to start GDB.

3283.63.text: I said 'GDB debugging,' so essentially it's going to be set to focusing on this debugging,

3295.54.text: I'm going to put a breakpoint.

3297.93.text: Essentially, the program is going to run until it hits at a certain breakpoint.

3301.16.text: I'm going to say break at the main function.

3304.91.text: So now I'm going to run debugging; so inside GDB I can run the code.

3312.68.text: It's running the program, and even though main was one of the first things that we wrote,

3317.71.text: we also have the include files; there's stuff going on already.

3320.87.text: It has the breakpoint at main.

3325.93.text: Let's say 'next,' so we can continue on.

3339.31.text: This is strange. So essentially we expect counters to be 0,

3342.98.text: but GDB is one step back, so whenever you say next,

3346.68.text: it says int counter = 0. That's the next thing that it's going to execute.

3350.35.text: Then you click--you can say next again, or you can just say 'n,'

3356.16.text: and now if you print counter, counter is 0, as we expect.

3362.40.text: Basically, it creates its own kind of variables for it, but whatever's there--

3367.57.text: like right here; that's what counter represents.

3372.12.text: So I'm going to click next, and I want to know what i is.

3375.18.text: You'll print i, i is 0, as we expect.

3381.27.text: Next again, it's indicating that it's going through the for loop again,

3385.63.text: so if I print i, for instance, I can see that we're on the--that i is 1 currently.

3392.97.text: So that's a way, that if you set a breakpoint at a certain function

3396.15.text: and then keep on going next, and then checking what i is,

3399.52.text: if you have a guess that maybe somewhere something's not happening as it should,

3405.79.text: and you suspect that maybe it's at the first index or the last index or something,

3411.34.text: you can use GDB, keep on printing i, to be able to check what those values are.

3420.11.text: So then, in GDB, because print and next are such common arguments,

3425.83.text: common commands, just like I abbreviated next to n,

3431.24.text: I can also just say p counter; that's still 0.

3442.01.text: Then I click next. I want to print counter again.

3446.79.text: And you're kind of wondering--well, I want counter to be a factorial function.

3459.01.text: Why--just in techniques of debugging--why might that be?

3463.93.text: Why is counter not increasing its value?

3473.10.text: Well, here I have--back in here I say counter = counter x i.

3479.32.text: So then if I go back to the beginning of my function,

3482.18.text: I see that when I printed i, i is 0, and what's 0 x anything?

3489.52.text: It's 0, right? So that's probably the reason why counter

3493.70.text: is never going to be any other number.

3496.96.text: So then what I might want to do is go back to my fuction,

3501.92.text: say, okay, well actually, I want to start it at 1.

3507.41.text: Is that going to solve things?

3512.15.text: Not quite, because counter is still 0 here.

3522.39.text: We want to reset our debugging tool, so let's quit.

3529.04.text: And then what we can do is we can GDB debugging again,

3534.00.text: put a break at main, and then run debugging again, next, next, next.

3545.62.text: Let's hit next a few times, and then we'll print counter, see that--

3552.52.text: we did not correctly make the file again.

3556.14.text: Even though we changed the source code, then we actually

3561.66.text: I believe that you can make--yeah.

3567.31.text: Within GDB itself, you can actually make the file.

3569.88.text: So you don't have to quit GDB again.

3571.88.text: You can go back to the source file, save it, back in GDB, you can make it again.

3580.85.text: We want to start it from the beginning because we have a new executable.

3585.90.text: We can go through a couple of times, and then print i, print counter, continue.

3594.87.text: All right. So now we see that counter is actually increasing its value as we want it to.

3599.09.text: That's just a tiny little bite-sized example of how you might use GDB

3603.34.text: to enter your code, print certain values, click next to proceed to the next line,

3609.70.text: and abbreviate it and print it out.

3612.96.text: Obviously, the code in scramble is a bit more complex than that, but what you can do

3618.69.text: is set a breakpoint at--you can set a breakpoint at your lookup functions, something like that.

3626.98.text: So whenever it reaches the point where it needs to look something up,

3629.44.text: then GDB will run everything up to that point and then you can start printing values out.

3637.34.text: Like is marks at this point false or is it true?

3642.03.text: That's probably something that you might want to use.

3646.58.text: GDB, don't stress too much about it,

3649.06.text: because we will go into more detail in lecture,

3651.27.text: but I just wanted to let you guys know how you might be able to use it

3654.57.text: if you're getting started with the pset and want to understand

3660.12.text: a better way than just putting print f statements and littering them all through your code.

3665.04.text: Having GDB to actually print it for you and being able to set those breakpoints

3670.43.text: so that your program can run up until a certain point

3672.98.text: and then allow you to really step into it and figure out the problem there.

3681.66.text: Right. So then if we look back to scramble, we've read the distribution code.

3689.60.text: We've talked about a way to iterate over 2D arrays, and you'll definitely

3695.67.text: be wanting to iterate over the 2D array when you come to drawing your game grid.

3700.91.text: We talked about the lookup function, about how we want to make sure of a couple of things.

3705.09.text: We want to make sure that we haven't been to the word before.

3708.30.text: We also want to make sure that it's actually in the dictionary.

3711.22.text: Then we talked about scramble, about how we want to rotate the board.

3714.22.text: And knowing that you might want to make a copy of something

3718.17.text: to be able to move it.

3720.44.text: Finally, we talked about case and sensitivity, about how you want to make sure

3723.25.text: that despite whatever combination of case that the user inputs,

3727.29.text: if it's a valid word in the dictionary,

3730.17.text: then it's going to be found correctly.

3734.40.text: So then all of that together is the scramble pset, and that is walkthrough 3.

3741.29.text: Thanks everyone for coming, and good luck with scramble.
